Jesse James.Action: Stands with coiled energy, appearing more angry than afraid, showing protective presence next to terrified Web Mimms.
Stands up calmly in the face of cannon and Gatling gun fire, showing coiled energy and anger rather than fear.
Is identified as the less skilled shooter compared to Frank James, implying a limitation in marksmanship.
Grabs Web to his chest and shields him with his own body during gunfire.
Tries to stop Web's bleeding with his bare hands after he is shot.
Orders Web to stay quiet and lie down, showing leadership and concern for his men.
Warns Frank to be careful and to check on Bob and Cole, demonstrating situational awareness and care for his team.
Shields Web with his own body under heavy Gatling fire, showing bravery and protective instincts.
Attempts to stop Web's bleeding with his bare hands, indicating desperation but limited medical skill.
Slaps Cole's shoulder and engages in friendly banter, smiling while discussing the plan.
Takes initiative to create a distraction by charging at the fortifications on horseback, risking his safety for the group.
Keeps walking confidently through rifle fire without hesitation.
Quickly assesses the situation and asks if there is a plan.
Immediately devises and executes a distraction plan by charging on horseback at full gallop.
Reveals his extensive armament in a dramatic and tactical manner, showing preparedness and confidence.
Leaps heroically over the barrier to lead an attack, firing accurately and protecting his men.
Shouts 'Come on, ya Yankee bastards!' while attacking.
Leaps over a fortification on horseback at full gallop, revealing multiple guns and immediately engages the enemy with precise shooting, taking down several soldiers before they can react.
Skillfully maneuvers his horse to avoid a Gatling gun volley, still shooting and killing enemies despite the danger.
After his horse is hit and falls, Jesse dives off, continues firing while rolling on the ground, smoothly draws new guns without interrupting his shooting.
Maintains composure and effectiveness under heavy fire, moving quickly and turning in chaos, remaining an untouchable blur.
Uses brutal violence against multiple Union soldiers in close combat, showing ruthless efficiency.
After being bayoneted, hesitates and shows mercy to a young Union soldier, recognizing his youth and inexperience, then waves him off without harm.
Waves off the boy with the guns, dismissing him curtly.
Engages in playful, teasing banter with Frank, showing camaraderie.
Accepts Cole's bear hug and friendly invitation to ride together.
Chooses to walk alone rather than ride with the group, indicating possible distance or reserve.
Quickly acts to distract the Missouri Rangers before Frank finishes planning.
Engages confidently with Frank, showing decisiveness and initiative.
Chooses to walk instead of riding with Cole and the Rangers, indicating possible self-restraint or strategic patience.
Shows clear-headedness and concern for his men by deciding to go home and protect their farms after the war ends.
Expresses determination to kill anyone who threatens their homes, indicating a protective but potentially violent stance.
Clearly assesses the situation after the war ends and proposes a decisive plan to return home quickly and defend their farms.
Demonstrates leadership by rallying the group with a confident and practical course of action.
Jesse warmly greets his companions with a sense of homecoming and camaraderie, saying 'Home, boys. Back to our farms.'
Jesse advises Cole to 'Pick your fights,' showing care and concern for his cousin's safety.
Jesse jokes about shooting his horse 'just on principle,' indicating a rough humor but not necessarily warmth.
Jerks his reins to lead the survivors away, showing control and leadership under pressure.
Recognizes the presence of Union soldiers and immediately assesses the situation as problematic, showing situational awareness.
Advises Cole to keep his hand off his hip and to pick fights wisely, demonstrating strategic thinking and restraint.
Makes a sarcastic comment about shooting his horse on principle, indicating a mix of humor and possible frustration but no clear impact on competence.
Stops Cole from cutting down the bodies to avoid alerting Union soldiers, showing strategic restraint.
Greets Zerelda Mimms warmly and is immediately smitten, showing friendly and sincere behavior.
Stops Cole from impulsively cutting down the bodies to avoid alerting Union soldiers, showing tactical caution and foresight.
Demonstrates awareness of the need for stealth and preparation in case of confrontation with enemies.
Jesse is obviously, immediately smitten when greeted by Zee, showing affectionate and warm feelings.
Jesse awkwardly tries to compliment Zee on her aging, showing sincere but clumsy friendliness.
Jesse and Frank rush to help Doc Mimms after Zee cries out and he slumps down, showing concern and care.
Jesse tells Doc Mimms a heroic story about Web, praising him and emphasizing his bravery, showing respect and warmth toward family.
Struggles to articulate a greeting to Zee, awkwardly correcting himself multiple times before pulling it together.
Quickly regains composure and shifts focus to important matters, initiating a serious conversation with Zee and her father.
Effectively narrates Web's heroic actions in battle, demonstrating awareness and confidence in recounting events.
Acknowledges Web Mimms' heroism and calls him a hero, showing respect and sincerity.
Offers help to Doc Mimms, expressing willingness to support others.
Swears to protect his farm and is ready to fight the railroad, showing determination but also a protective attitude toward his home and community.
Recognizes the threat posed by the railroad and is determined to defend his farm, showing resolve and awareness of his situation.
Questions the plausibility of fabricating a story to avoid trouble, indicating skepticism and critical thinking.
Expresses a willingness to go to war with the railroad to protect his land, showing confidence and decisiveness.
Does not fully grasp the legal and political dangers explained by Doc Mimms about the consequences of their actions and affiliations.
Listens quietly as Zee thanks them sincerely and emotionally, showing restraint and respect.
Stares longingly at Zee's door after leaving, indicating emotional attachment and sensitivity.
Responds to Frank's teasing with a sharp retort but no real hostility.
Agrees that the story Zee told might work to convince others, showing quick judgment and adaptability.
Stares silently at the door after leaving Zee's house, appearing distracted and emotionally affected, delaying action.
Quietly acknowledges and appreciates Ma being kind to Comanche Tom, their Native American friend.
Casually admits to killing 'a fair number' of Yankees when asked by Ma.
Responds calmly and confidently to his mother's hysteria, indicating emotional control and presence of mind.
Acknowledges killing 'a fair number' of Yankees without hesitation, showing straightforwardness and confidence in his actions.
Quietly nods at Comanche Tom, showing awareness and subtle social intelligence.
Makes a dry, witty remark about Jesus talking back, indicating quick thinking and a sharp mind.
Engages in lighthearted teasing and joking with Cole and Frank, sharing laughter and playful banter.
Shows affection and protectiveness by defending Zerelda from teasing.
Thanks Cole for his help with the farm work.
Acknowledges the harsh realities of war, showing a reflective and sincere side.
Successfully drives a post straight into a hole, showing practical skill and physical capability.
Engages in witty banter and uses humor to defuse tension, demonstrating social intelligence and confidence.
Shows awareness of others' feelings by agreeing to stop teasing about Zerelda, indicating emotional competence.
Does not display any signs of confusion or hesitation during the conversation, maintaining control and confidence.
Responds to Parker's greeting with a sarcastic comment 'Easterners.'
Engages in light banter with Parker about the railroad president, showing familiarity and a bit of humor.
Cole says Jesse is 'one terrifying sonofabitch with those guns,' indicating Jesse's skill and fearsome reputation with firearms.
Jesse responds to Parker's introduction with a sarcastic and witty remark about the railroad moving west to avoid being underwater, showing quick thinking and confidence.
Draws and cocks two Colts to defend family land against forced sale.
Draws and cocks two Colts quickly and confidently in a tense standoff, showing readiness and skill.
Shrugs off question about where he got guns, showing casual confidence but no hostility.
Comments 'Somebody's in a vengeful smiting mood today' after Ma agrees to bury bodies secretly, indicating a sardonic but not cruel attitude.
Participates in a community meeting with men and women, engaging in collective discussion about railroad land issues.
Draws and cocks two Colts quickly and confidently in a tense situation.
Shrugs off question about where he got the guns, indicating calmness and control.
Acknowledges the value of reading and understanding legal documents related to the railroad land rights.
Notices Zee's comforting hand on his shoulder, acknowledges it silently.
Sighs and asks how many people Cole killed after hearing about the violence.
Sighs and calmly asks how many enemies Cole killed after hearing about the violent encounter.
Tells the crowd to go home and swear they know nothing to protect them from danger.
Softly reassures Doc Mimms that no more Liberty boys will be hanged.
Refuses Jim Younger's request to join, citing his youth and experience.
Dismisses Zee's involvement by telling him to go home despite Zee's insistence on helping.
Calmly commands the crowd to disperse and instructs them to swear they know nothing, showing control and strategic thinking.
Refuses to let Jim Younger join because he is too young, demonstrating judgment and protective leadership.
Dismisses Zee's input initially by telling him to go home, but listens when Zee presses about needing information on the hangings.
Smiles while discussing a dangerous plan against overwhelming odds.
Smiles confidently when facing overwhelming odds: seven men against a Union regiment and Pinkerton detectives in broad daylight on Main Street.
Leaps from horse to slam into the Hangman, disrupting an execution and aiding a rescue.
Appears masked on horseback, leaps onto the hangman, and brings him down, disrupting the execution.
Coordinates with other masked rescuers who crash through a general store window on horseback and open fire, creating chaos and enabling escape.
Cuts the rope on Cole's wrists, freeing him from capture.
Exchanges a look with Cole, showing trust and camaraderie before stepping away.
Leaps on a horse to escape with Cole, prioritizing his comrade's safety.
Allows Zee to hide him from Union soldiers, trusting her to protect him.
Smiles in his sleep, showing a gentle, non-threatening demeanor despite being a fugitive.
Remains hidden and protected by Zee when Union soldiers search the house, avoiding capture despite being badly wounded.
Appears groggy and weak, unable to respond clearly when questioned or confronted.
Zee immediately moves to support him when he comes through the door gingerly after being sick.
Engages in playful, warm teasing and affectionate banter with Zee, showing mutual care and warmth.
Modestly deflects praise for rescuing Cole, acknowledging others' risks.
Shares a warm, sincere moment of mutual affection and understanding with Zee.
Comes through the door moving gingerly after being sick for two weeks but insists on being up and about, showing determination and confidence in recovery.
Acknowledges he wasn't the only one risking his neck during the rescue, showing awareness and humility.
Engages in warm, lighthearted banter with Zee, showing social ease and emotional intelligence.
Does not show any signs of confusion or hesitation when interacting with Frank and Doc Mimms, indicating clear-headedness and readiness to resume normal activities.
Asks Doc Mimms if he can come by and take Zee out to a social gathering, showing consideration and a desire to include others.
Glances exchanged with Zee and she withdraws demurely, indicating a respectful and possibly protective dynamic.
Glares at Frank when Frank jokes about chaperoning, showing irritation but also a protective attitude toward Zee.
Wincing at Cole's bear hug, indicating some discomfort with overt displays but still accepting the friendly gesture.
Straightens up and hops easily into the carriage, showing physical confidence and readiness.
Awkwardly tries to ask Doc Mimms if he can come by and take Zee out, hesitating and stumbling over words.
Slowly glares at Frank after a sarcastic comment, showing controlled assertiveness.
Arrives at the party with Zee and is immediately greeted with applause and respect, indicating social competence and reputation.
Swings Zee into a group of dancers and joins in the Two-Step smoothly, engaging warmly in the party.
Shares a playful, imaginative conversation with Zee about being a river pirate, showing humor and openness.
Expresses hope to find the right girl and describes her with affectionate, teasing qualities.
Jesse swings Zee into a group of dancers and joins the Two-Step, showing he is smooth and confident in social settings.
Jesse carries a lantern and leads Zee to a quiet, scenic spot, demonstrating thoughtfulness and a sense of direction.
Jesse reflects on his childhood dreams and shows self-awareness and humor about his past ambitions.
Jesse jokes about being a river pirate and engages playfully with Zee, indicating social ease and wit.
Jesse admits he has mostly grown out of childish fantasies, showing maturity and realistic self-assessment.
Engages in playful, affectionate banter with Zee, culminating in a sincere kiss.
Responds calmly and quickly to the barn fire, showing concern and readiness to act.
Quotes Shakespeare awkwardly but with intention to impress Zee, showing some confidence but limited skill.
Quickly reacts to the barn fire by mounting his horse and galloping off with Frank, showing situational awareness and decisiveness.
Cradles his severely burned mother, openly crying and showing deep emotional pain.
Urgently tries to get help for his mother, showing concern and care.
Expresses rage and pain loudly after his mother's death, revealing sincere emotional vulnerability.
Jesse and Frank quickly mount horses and gallop off at the first sign of danger, showing quick reaction and decisiveness.
Jesse ventures too close to the burning house, resulting in his coat catching fire, showing a lack of caution despite the danger.
Despite the danger, Jesse tries to get close to his mother and shows emotional strength in a crisis, indicating determination and focus.
Jesse ignores Frank's attempt to put out his burning coat, prioritizing his emotional response over practical safety.
Jesse quickly decides to get his mother to Doc Mimms, showing presence of mind and prioritization of urgent needs.
Jesse openly cries and howls in rage and pain, showing emotional vulnerability but possibly a loss of control in a critical moment.
After the tragedy, Jesse rejects the idea of moving on and rebuilding, indicating a lack of practical forward planning or acceptance.
Rejects impulsive violent revenge, proposes strategic harassment instead.
Encourages and supports Cole's idea to gather intelligence through a girl he knows.
Dismisses Frank's despair and refuses to engage in emotional consolation.
Responds to Zee's apology with a matter-of-fact statement about leaving, without emotional engagement.
Rejects rash violence and instead proposes a strategic plan to harass supply lines, showing understanding of enemy strength and resourcefulness.
Commands respect and confidence from his gang, who agree with his plan despite initial doubts.
Takes initiative by preparing weapons and supplies, demonstrating readiness and leadership.
Kisses Zee gently before leaving, despite her anger and heartbreak.
Refuses to answer Zee's question about whose justice he serves.
Declares intent to bring enemies to ashes and make them cry in their sleep.
Warns bank customers about stolen payroll before robbing the bank.
Draws guns on bank manager and robs the bank in front of customers including a mother and child.
Confidently asserts that laws don't affect certain men, showing a clear personal code and resolve.

Responds calmly and authoritatively in the bank, using deception and intimidation effectively.
Does not answer Zee's question about whose justice he serves, indicating possible avoidance or internal conflict.

Engages in a staredown with the Bank Manager, asserting control and confidence.
Half covers his eyes and turns his head when Cole prepares to shoot a man, showing some discomfort or hesitation.
Raises a hand to stop the gang from shooting the sheriff, offers him a choice to avoid violence.

Leads the gang in a successful bank robbery and manages the confrontation with the sheriff calmly and confidently, defusing a potentially violent situation.
Uses clear communication and commands respect from both his gang and the sheriff, showing situational awareness and leadership.
Suggests taking some stolen money to give to neighbors in Liberty who are hurting.
Calms the gang down by reminding them the money isn't truly theirs.
Engages in a tense leadership dispute with Cole, but acknowledges Cole's past leadership and contributions.
Plans and executes a bank robbery successfully with Cole, demonstrating leadership and tactical skill.

Calms the gang down and provides a realistic perspective on the loot, showing confidence and control.
Engages in a tense leadership rivalry with Cole but maintains composure and asserts his role effectively.
Nods silently when Frank suggests a plan, showing restraint and consideration.
Grins and slaps Cole on the back after discussing plans, showing camaraderie and friendliness.
Shares the newspaper with the gang, reads the report aloud, and acknowledges their notoriety with a mix of pride and humor.
Expresses intent to 'set the record straight' themselves after the false reports, showing loyalty and protectiveness toward the gang's reputation.
Reads the newspaper about their bank robbery and confidently states they will have to set the record straight themselves next time.
Acknowledges the inflated loss reported by the bank officials compared to their actual take, showing awareness of the situation.
Leads a raid that kills several Pinkerton guards, successfully robs the payroll office, and sabotages the railway tracks for half a mile, causing significant delay.
His horse tramples Alan Pinkerton, causing Pinkerton to limp, indicating a lack of control or recklessness.
Authors a bold newspaper article claiming responsibility for a daring robbery, demonstrating confidence and psychological savvy.
Successfully outguns and outsmarts a larger force of Pinkerton detectives during the robbery.
Provokes authorities by openly taunting them through the press, showing strategic risk-taking.
Warns the train engineer with clear signs to slow down and avoid danger.
Grins as the engineer and fireman hang their heads after narrowly avoiding danger.
Sets up a clever and effective fake dynamite warning to stop a train just in time, demonstrating planning and control.
Enters a bank dressed in suits despite being wanted, showing boldness and confidence in disguise.
Hands a bill to the teller and politely asks if it can be changed, engaging in a seemingly sincere interaction despite the bill being counterfeit.
Draws a weapon when the teller calls the bill counterfeit, showing readiness for violence rather than tolerance or friendliness.
Uses a counterfeit bill as a test to distract the teller and gain access to real bills for comparison, demonstrating cleverness and confidence.
Draws his weapon quickly when confronted, showing readiness and decisiveness.
Tears down his wanted poster and autographs it for a young boy.
Tears down his wanted poster and autographs it for a young boy.
Nods knowingly with Cole while riding hard and whistling, showing calm awareness of their situation.
Acknowledges the point made by others without argument ('Can't argue with that.')

Leads the gang to successfully rob a bank quickly and escape with full saddlebags.
Operates across four states, using vast terrain and local support to evade Pinkerton detectives.
Remains publicly visible in some Missouri towns as a hero despite being a wanted outlaw.
Donates money to farmers, churches, and sharecroppers enabling them to build a school.
Comments that it is a shame people shoot at them instead of handing over money.
Sits with his brothers in church with heads bowed during collection plate.
Successfully robs a payroll coach guarded by Pinkerton agents, killing two guards and taking the money.

Acknowledges Bob's feelings of being left out and seems to understand the issue with the wanted posters.

Beckons the bartender after Jim leaves, indicating initiative and possibly strategic thinking in managing the social situation.
Consistently robs banks within a predictable travel radius, showing strategic planning and understanding of his environment.

Shoves Cole and Frank down to protect them from gunfire.

Having a relaxed picnic with Zee, showing a tender domestic moment.

Physically active and playful, pulling Zee up and engaging in swimming and kissing, showing confidence in personal interactions.

Maintains physical fitness and composure despite being chained in a dank cell.
Shares a close, trusting friendship and family bond with Cole, as noted by Comanche Tom.
Does push-ups easily despite being chained in a dank cell, showing physical strength and mental resilience.

Accepts a cigar from Pinkerton and shares a moment of mutual recognition despite being enemies.
Engages in a somewhat friendly, candid conversation with Pinkerton, showing a degree of openness and sincerity.
Expresses a desire to kill Thaddeus Rains, indicating vengefulness and lack of tolerance.
Accurately deduces the location of extra men in town based on cattle branding, showing situational awareness and intelligence.
Recalls narrowly escaping an ambush and recognizes the threat, indicating alertness and survival skills.
Acknowledges the inevitability of his capture and execution with calmness, showing confidence and acceptance of consequences.
Expresses regret for not taking a more decisive action (killing Thaddeus Rains) earlier, implying a missed opportunity and some hesitation.
Remembers Parker and calls out that he killed his Ma, showing personal memory and directness.
Winks after reminding Rains he made him think twice about burning homes, showing a cocky but somewhat playful attitude.
Engages in tense but somewhat familiar banter with Pinkerton, indicating a complex relationship.
Engages in confident banter with Pinkerton, showing composure despite being captured and in irons.
Remembers Parker and calls him out for killing his mother, demonstrating awareness and psychological insight.
Winks and retorts to Rains about making him think twice about burning homes, showing defiance and mental resilience.
Allows himself to be sucker punched by Parker, indicating a momentary lapse in vigilance.
Threatens Rains with a visit, showing determination and steel in his voice.
Notices the club car several cars away from his prison car despite being surrounded by Pinkerton detectives, indicating situational awareness.
Threatens Rains with a promise to pay him a visit, showing confidence and intimidation.
Despite being chained and surrounded by ten armed detectives, Jesse remains calm and observant, suggesting mental resilience and composure.
No attempt to escape or resist while chained and guarded, possibly indicating restraint or strategic patience rather than incompetence.
Teases and mocks the Burly Detective with insults and taunts.
Grins and remains defiant even after being struck and threatened.
Stares down a gun barrel pointed at his face and responds with a low, terrifying voice, then immediately kicks the attacker in a vulnerable spot, causing the gun to fire harmlessly.
Provokes the burly detective with insults despite being outnumbered and in a confined space, risking escalation.
Uses violence and gunfire to fight off detectives and Pinkertons aggressively during escape.

Backhands the detective with the heavy chain, catches the dropped gun, flips the chain tight, slides over detectives' heads, fires gun to blow open gun box, shoots guards effectively, and uses dual guns rapidly to take down multiple enemies.
Improvises a gunbelt holding six Colts and uses the chain from his restraints to support himself while running and shooting along the side of the train car, maintaining offensive pressure.
Runs along the side of the moving train, shoots accurately while moving, and jumps onto the roof despite heavy gunfire.
Realizes he is trapped when detectives appear ahead and behind him on the train roof, showing situational awareness.
Does not panic or hesitate despite being trapped and under heavy fire, maintaining composure.
Points gun at Pinkerton's head and fires, but does not kill him.
Says 'That was for my Ma. Now this is for everybody else.' before aiming at Rains.
Breaks tension by offering to buy Rains' watch for a fair price instead of shooting him.
Leaps down from the top of the train onto Pinkerton and wrestles him, then confidently points a gun at Pinkerton's head and fires, showing physical skill and decisiveness.
Engages in a tense standoff with Rains, using psychological tactics by commenting on Rains' watch and offering to buy it for a dollar, demonstrating cleverness and control of the situation.
Turns back along the top of the train after seeing Rains is gone, indicating situational awareness and quick reaction.
Flips a dollar coin to Rains after intimidating him and taking his watch, delivering a threatening message.
Thanks Pinkerton after he declares no interest in Tennessee and spares him, showing a moment of civility.
Responds respectfully and playfully to Zee's threats and admonishments, showing a friendly and sincere rapport.
Receives a bear hug from Cole, indicating camaraderie and warmth within his gang.
Greets Cole warmly with a bear hug and mutual expressions of missing each other.
Reassures Cole that he never doubted their loyalty despite being caught.
Acknowledges and appreciates Zerelda's role in recruiting riders.
Expresses gratitude to Frank for the distraction during the escape.
Says goodbye to the gang with a plan to leave outlaw life behind, showing sincerity.
Jesse confidently decides to leave the gang and plans to buy a farm in Tennessee with his wife, showing clear intention and control over his future.
Jesse appreciates Frank's distraction during their escape, indicating awareness and gratitude for tactical support.
Jesse does not question or challenge the new leadership or the changed dynamics in the gang after his departure, showing possible detachment or lack of engagement.
Jesse fails to understand Cole's emotional state, indicating a momentary lack of insight into his close associates' feelings.
Frank remembers Jesse as a man who saved many people from the railroad and was 'a real interestin' fella to have around,' showing a fond and respectful remembrance.
Frank softens the harsh edges of Jesse's past, allowing a kinder version of his story to be told to Jimmy, indicating a protective and warm attitude toward Jesse's memory.
Saved a lot of folk from the railroad.
Killed a lot of men, too.
